quotes.topic_title: Engineers as adults and leadership accountability
quotes.text: I think that we often treat engineers a little bit like children instead of giving them the responsibilities and ability to actually thrive as adults.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Challenges leaders to stop infantilizing engineers and instead give them real ownership to accelerate growth.

quotes.topic_title: Engineers as adults and leadership accountability
quotes.text: Well, that's actually not good for the engineers to be sheltered from what is important.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A clear principle: shielding engineers from high-impact work harms their development and organizational effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Engineers as adults and leadership accountability
quotes.text: I think we're coming back this moment where we can actually treat engineers like our peers and put them into really senior leadership roles and not have this kind of baseline assumption of like, "Oh, we have to coddle them or hide them from the real problems."
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Reframes the current environment as an opportunity to elevate engineers into senior leadership and direct problem ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Engineers as adults and leadership accountability
quotes.text: And this is how they're going to get the opportunity to grow as well.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Connects accountability and exposure to real problems directly to engineer growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Will shares advice on developing your engineering strategy and strategy in general, how to improve the relationship between an eng manager and a PM, how he finds time to write, while also working an intense full-time job, how he recommends approaching measuring engineering productivity, how to develop your company values, an amazing story about his time at Digg and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A compact preview of several practitioner-relevant areas (strategy, EM–PM collaboration, productivity measurement, values) that signals the episode’s actionable focus.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you've tried measuring developer productivity, you know that there are a lot of basic metrics out there and a lot of ways to do this wrong.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a common trap—misusing simplistic productivity metrics—framing measurement as an area where teams often make avoidable mistakes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: DX tackles this problem by combining qualitative and quantitative insights, giving you full clarity into how your developers are doing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a concrete methodology—mixing qualitative + quantitative signals—as a more holistic approach to understanding developer productivity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you've tried measuring developer productivity, you know that there are a lot of basic metrics out there and a lot of ways to do this wrong. And getting that full view of productivity is still really hard.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a common measurement trap: simplistic productivity metrics are easy to misuse and rarely capture the full picture.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: DX tackles this problem by combining qualitative and quantitative insights, giving you full clarity into how your developers are doing.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Offers a practical measurement approach: blend qualitative and quantitative signals to assess developer productivity more reliably.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: DX is used by both startups and Fortune 500 companies, including companies like Twilio, Amplitude, eBay, Brex, Toast, Pfizer, and Proctor and Gamble.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides concrete adoption examples that serve as a credibility/data point for the tool’s applicability across company sizes and industries.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A memorable, experience-based observation that can guide practitioners to design import flows assuming messy real-world inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You keep adding features to your spreadsheet importer, but customers keep running into issues. Six months later, you're fixing it. Another date conversion edge-case bug.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Captures the recurring maintenance cost pattern of building CSV importers in-house, warning teams about long-tail edge cases.

quotes.topic_title: What’s changing in engineering post-ZIRP
quotes.text: When I was at Uber, some days I would do six interviews back to back. I would just be in a conference room and at some point you can't even remember who you're talking to because you talk to so many people, one after another after another.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A vivid data point illustrating how hypergrowth pushed engineering leaders into nonstop hiring mode, often at the expense of other leadership work.

quotes.topic_title: What’s changing in engineering post-ZIRP
quotes.text: A lot of engineering managers are spending half their time or more hiring 18 months ago and now they're doing two interviews a month or less. Maybe zero interviews a month.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Quantifies the market shift and highlights why leaders must reallocate time from hiring to execution, prioritization, and team health.

quotes.topic_title: What’s changing in engineering post-ZIRP
quotes.text: Instead, all these different competencies that have become more critical or a really great engineering director might've just been spending their time hiring really well and that could be a top performer and now that person can't actually demonstrate what they're great at.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive performance trap: leaders optimized for hiring can look ineffective when the environment no longer rewards that strength.

quotes.topic_title: What’s changing in engineering post-ZIRP
quotes.text: So that person might be perceived as a low performer if they're not also figuring out how to lead the team, getting deeper into the details and also sometimes getting into the figuring out what is the right allocation, what is the right sizing of the engineering teams, this is stuff that we weren't talking about much or maybe if you really pissed off the CEO, maybe an infrastructure you just grew a little bit slower next year, but different ballgame at this point where teams are actually disappearing, teams are getting cut down, teams are getting consolidated.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Actionable reframing of what “good leadership” now requires: org design, allocation, and sizing amid consolidation rather than pure headcount growth.

quotes.topic_title: Engineer leverage, coddling, and senior roles
quotes.text: One of my hobby horses is that I think that we often treat engineers a little bit like children instead of giving them the responsibilities and ability to actually thrive as adults.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Challenges the common management instinct to protect engineers, arguing that real responsibility is essential for growth and effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Engineer leverage, coddling, and senior roles
quotes.text: Well, that's actually not good for the engineers to be sheltered from what is important.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A concise principle practitioners can apply: expose engineers to business-critical work rather than insulating them from it.

quotes.topic_title: Engineer leverage, coddling, and senior roles
quotes.text: But now something that I love is we get to give engineers real hard problems and we get to actually hold them accountable. And that means we can put them in senior roles.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Links accountability + hard problems to unlocking senior IC leadership, a practical lens for designing roles and expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Engineer leverage, coddling, and senior roles
quotes.text: One of the challenges is if we aren't comfortable holding engineers accountable because we just want to retain all the engineers, then we can't put them in senior roles.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive tradeoff: retention-driven coddling can block the creation of true senior engineer roles.

quotes.topic_title: Engineer leverage, coddling, and senior roles
quotes.text: And so I think we're actually seeing a bit of a shift where we can actually hold them accountable, which means we can put them in senior roles, which means the engineers can actually get what they've been trying to get the entire time, but we haven't been able to because we've been coddling them a little bit too much.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Summarizes a causal chain practitioners can use as a mental model for evolving engineering culture and career ladders.

quotes.topic_title: Systems thinking: definition and pitfalls
quotes.text: I think a lot of people who get too far in systems thinking make the same mistake where they think reality is wrong and reality is never wrong. Reality is always right. Your model is always wrong if it's in conflict with reality. But that conflict, that gap is really interesting and that's where you can learn.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A crisp rule for using models responsibly: treat mismatches with reality as learning signals, not proof reality is “wrong.”

quotes.topic_title: Systems thinking: definition and pitfalls
quotes.text: we got so caught up in the analysis that we lost track of whether we're actually improving things.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A concrete warning from Stripe incident management that analysis can displace real improvement work.

quotes.topic_title: Systems thinking: definition and pitfalls
quotes.text: Hey, we weren't actually prioritizing improvements, we were just prioritizing measurement.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for teams: measurement can become the goal instead of the means.

quotes.topic_title: Systems thinking: definition and pitfalls
quotes.text: And you do have to cut at some point to actually make impact. But we just got caught a little bit there.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Memorable execution reminder that learning/measurement must eventually convert into action to create outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Systems thinking: definition and pitfalls
quotes.text: Systems thinking is basically you try to think about stocks and flows.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A simple, portable definition practitioners can use to model real-world processes (pipelines, incidents, etc.).

quotes.topic_title: Applying systems thinking to hiring pipelines
quotes.text: The first thing to do is to get a model out there of any sort. And so you think about your stocks.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A practical starting point for systems thinking: build even a rough stock-and-flow model before debating solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Applying systems thinking to hiring pipelines
quotes.text: But then as you get deeper into it, you start to actually see interesting things. And so for a lot of candidate or a lot of pipelines, the biggest issue is hiring managers don't want to extend any offers because the hiring managers can't get to confidence on any candidate.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Highlights a common hidden bottleneck—offer conviction—revealed only when you model the pipeline stages explicitly.

quotes.topic_title: Applying systems thinking to hiring pipelines
quotes.text: Manager wants to extend a ton of offers. They do extend them and none of them actually accept.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A crisp diagnostic pattern that separates “decision-making” problems from “closing” problems in hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Applying systems thinking to hiring pipelines
quotes.text: You can see the drop-offs and this helps you figure out where should you go try to fix things first.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: use observed stage-by-stage drop-offs to prioritize interventions rather than guessing.

quotes.topic_title: Applying systems thinking to hiring pipelines
quotes.text: I think we've all worked in companies where you roll out big changes with no data behind them because like, "Oh, it feels like we're not hard enough in how we evaluate candidates or something."
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Challenges “vibes-based” process changes and motivates grounding hiring tweaks in pipeline data.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy: write it down and embrace boring
quotes.text: The first rule of strategy is that if you write it down, then you can improve it.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A simple operating principle: documentation is what makes strategy inspectable and improvable rather than implicit and untestable.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy: write it down and embrace boring
quotes.text: If it's not written down, it's hard to say if this PM is just not a good PM or if they're trying to apply the strategy that they've misunderstood or if they actually are correctly applying the strategy from the head of product that's just not appropriate to the problems they're working on, how do you debug any of that?
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Explains the practical debugging value of a written strategy: it separates execution issues from misunderstanding and from flaws in the strategy itself.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy: write it down and embrace boring
quotes.text: But the second big theme on strategy I think about is that often good strategy is so boring.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that effective engineering strategy often looks like unsexy constraints rather than exciting innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy: write it down and embrace boring
quotes.text: For example, on the engineering side of thing, a common strategy that's really good but very boring is we only use the tools we have today.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A concrete, actionable strategy pattern: standardize tooling to reduce churn and focus effort on higher-value problems.

quotes.topic_title: Engineering strategy: write it down and embrace boring
quotes.text: And at Carta, when I joined one of the engineers, Eric Vogel wrote the standard kit and that is our strategy of the tools we use.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A specific example of “boring strategy” implemented as a written standard toolkit that guides engineering decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy examples: constraints at Uber and Stripe
quotes.text: Richard Rumelt, definition of strategy is basically three components. There's a diagnosis. What is the current status quo? What are the things that are real today? There are guiding policies which are basically based on the diagnoses, how do you want to address them? And there's actions. And actions are how are we going to implement these guiding policies.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A practical, reusable framework for turning “strategy” into concrete decisions and execution steps.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy examples: constraints at Uber and Stripe
quotes.text: At Uber, we only used our own data centers. We didn't use the cloud. And this has changed since the era I was there, but in the 2014 era, no cloud, and we had a strict no cloud policy.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive constraint example that shows how a hard policy can shape speed and optionality.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy examples: constraints at Uber and Stripe
quotes.text: But it also meant that we were able to spin up in China in literally three months and some surreal stories from that. We couldn't fit our racks into the data centers, so they had to take the roof off the data center and lift the racks in with the crane.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A vivid operational story illustrating how infrastructure choices can enable rapid geopolitical expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy examples: constraints at Uber and Stripe
quotes.text: But the goal of good strategy is not to appease everyone. The goal of good strategy is to dictate how we invest the limited capacities we have or the limited capabilities we have into the problems we care about.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A crisp principle for making strategy decisions when teams disagree and resources are constrained.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy examples: constraints at Uber and Stripe
quotes.text: A common theme across all these examples is essentially constraint, deciding we will constrain our options to move faster and focus on the things that really matter.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: strategy as intentionally chosen constraints to increase focus and velocity.

quotes.topic_title: How to get better at strategy
quotes.text: In solving the constraints is to me, I think the most interesting thing that strategy really does, and I think when we talk about bad strategy usually is because the diagnosis is bad and it's usually because people are exerting what they want to be true on constraints where it's like, "Hey, we can do all of these projects at once."
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Frames strategy as primarily about accurately diagnosing and working within constraints rather than wishful planning.

quotes.topic_title: How to get better at strategy
quotes.text: And often that's just not true, but it's hard to convince people that when they're the CEO or they are really committed to believing it, but almost all bad strategies basically come down from a willful disbelief of what an accurate diagnosis is, which means then your guiding policies are kind of incoherent to begin with.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Highlights a contrarian root cause of bad strategy: leaders refusing to accept reality, leading to incoherent policies.

quotes.topic_title: How to get better at strategy
quotes.text: First, I think the Richard Rumelt book, I think Good Strategy, Bad Strategy is probably the right starting point.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, actionable starting point for practitioners who want to improve their strategy skills.

quotes.topic_title: How to get better at strategy
quotes.text: Also Thinking in Systems, I mentioned that before related to systems thinking, a big part of strategy is being able to model the reality so we can improve your diagnosis.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Connects strategy to systems thinking: better models of reality improve diagnosis and therefore strategy quality.

quotes.topic_title: How to get better at strategy
quotes.text: But I think there's still the missing canonical book is kind of missing on this one.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Points out a gap in the field—no widely accepted “canonical” engineering strategy text—suggesting an opportunity for new thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Writing output: motivation, energy, and longevity
quotes.text: I feel really strongly that you can write a lot more if you write what you want to write.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A simple productivity principle: volume and consistency come more from intrinsic motivation than from forcing output.

quotes.topic_title: Writing output: motivation, energy, and longevity
quotes.text: To me, the biggest strength of writing what you want is you get to write where there's energy and you don't have to write where there's no energy, which takes you really, really negative.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A practical energy-management framework for sustaining long-term creative output by following “energy” and avoiding energy drains.

quotes.topic_title: Writing output: motivation, energy, and longevity
quotes.text: So I started writing this infrastructure engineering book a couple of years ago. It just wasn't there. I just couldn't get it to come together and so I just stopped. I'm not writing it anymore.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A concrete example of quitting a project when it doesn’t cohere—counter to the common “always finish what you start” advice.

quotes.topic_title: Writing output: motivation, energy, and longevity
quotes.text: And this also ties into how I write books, which is that I basically write the entire thing before I start working with a publisher.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A process methodology that reduces external constraints and preserves creative control by completing a full draft before involving a publisher.

quotes.topic_title: Writing output: motivation, energy, and longevity
quotes.text: I don't write what I'm not thinking about and I don't write for any audience, I just write what is interesting to me.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A contrarian stance on audience-first writing that emphasizes authenticity and sustained interest as the driver of quality output.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of fast-growing companies like Gusto, Qom, Quora, and Modern Treasury trust Vanta to help build scale, manage and demonstrate their security and compliance programs and get ready for audits in weeks, not months.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete outcome (audit readiness in weeks vs. months) and provides recognizable examples of companies using the approach.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: By offering the most in-demand, security and privacy frameworks such as SOC 2, ISO 27001, GDPR, HIPAA and many more, Vanta helps companies obtain the reports they need to accelerate growth, build efficient compliance processes, mitigate risks to their businesses, and build trust with external stakeholders.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Connects compliance work to business outcomes (growth, efficiency, risk reduction, stakeholder trust) and names specific frameworks practitioners may need to support.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a specific adoption and automation data point that quantifies how much compliance effort can be reduced with automation.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical writing workflow with a demanding job
quotes.text: I would guess about a thousand. That would roughly be my assumption. I think there are a few years where I wrote hundreds of posts, and so if you do that like three years, it's not that hard to get to a thousand from there.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A concrete output benchmark that reframes “consistency” as bursts of high-volume writing over a few years.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical writing workflow with a demanding job
quotes.text: I think the biggest risk to writers is quitting.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A simple, counterintuitive risk model: persistence matters more than early growth rate or trend-chasing.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical writing workflow with a demanding job
quotes.text: What really matters is finding something you can actually keep doing for the next decade. That's way harder than doing it for one year.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A long-horizon sustainability test for choosing topics and formats that won’t burn you out.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical writing workflow with a demanding job
quotes.text: the biggest thing that I found is finding things to write about that also directly relate to what I'm working on.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A tactical workflow: align writing with current work to reduce context-switching and make writing easier to sustain.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical writing workflow with a demanding job
quotes.text: I think writing about related topics is a great way to refine your thinking and improve your performance. It's not like a conflict or you do one.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: Reframes writing as a performance tool for demanding roles, not a competing side project.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for aspiring writers: artifacts vs consistency
quotes.text: I tell people, if you just want to write something that is going to help advance your career, you should really focus on writing two or three really good things and spend a ton of time drafting, revising, getting feedback.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A practical strategy for career-focused writing: prioritize a small number of high-quality artifacts over ongoing publishing.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for aspiring writers: artifacts vs consistency
quotes.text: Don't start a newsletter if you just want to advance yourself in the industry a little bit. Just write two or three really good things.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that challenges the default “start a newsletter” advice for professional advancement.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for aspiring writers: artifacts vs consistency
quotes.text: But if your goal is to write a lot consistently over time, my biggest advice would be just publish.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for consistent writers: bias toward shipping rather than endless drafting.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for aspiring writers: artifacts vs consistency
quotes.text: Sometimes people will send you silly feedback and I just don't respond to that stuff anymore. You never know why people send you something like that. I think trying to debug people you don't know is a bad use of time. It's just kind of like, "Thank you. Move on to the next. Don't even spend time worrying about it."
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A mental model for handling unhelpful feedback: don’t waste cycles diagnosing strangers’ motivations—acknowledge and move on.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for aspiring writers: artifacts vs consistency
quotes.text: I think people way overestimate how much anyone cares about what you put out. Most people are going to look at it for three seconds and be like, "Eh." That's the worst case scenario basically is just like, "I don't care about this."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A reframing that lowers the perceived stakes of publishing, making it easier to start and iterate in public.

quotes.topic_title: Improving PM–engineering relationships and incentives
quotes.text: So one, understanding the incentives. The other piece though, and I think this is the more common case or just that the EM or the PM just don't understand the other person's needs and they start arguing before understanding. So my biggest advice to both the EMs and the PMs, is before you try to solve the conflict, it's like pushing to ship this feature, pushing to change the approach. Just make sure you actually understand what they care about.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A practical conflict-resolution heuristic: diagnose incentives and needs before debating solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Improving PM–engineering relationships and incentives
quotes.text: There is this idea that you have to make trade-offs and that there are tons of hard trade-offs to be made in the field, but my experience is if you really deeply understand what everyone wants, there's usually a compromised solution that gives everyone exactly what they want. That doesn't take more time. You just have to be willing to dig deeper into it and understand the true needs for each party, which is often not what they're saying by the way, which is part of the confusion.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive model: many “trade-offs” dissolve when you uncover underlying needs rather than stated positions.

quotes.topic_title: Improving PM–engineering relationships and incentives
quotes.text: Is it ever this simple? It's really never that simple. People create simplistic narratives to find villains that they work with. There are no villains in the workplace. They're just people with complex incentives that are doing complex things.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A reframing tool for PM–EM tension: replace blame narratives with incentive-aware empathy.

quotes.topic_title: Improving PM–engineering relationships and incentives
quotes.text: So my biggest thing has been trying to force this idea that EM/PM pairs are peers and they generally have the same performance rating.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: A concrete incentive-alignment mechanism: tie EM and PM outcomes together via shared performance evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Improving PM–engineering relationships and incentives
quotes.text: Henry, our CEO has a blog post about trifectas in doing that, but not just for EM and for PM, but also for that business leadership as well where you all get graded the same score based on your ability to evaluate and solve for the entire set of constraints, not just your functional constraints.
quotes.speaker: Will Larson
quotes.context: An org-design pattern (“trifectas”) that extends shared accountability across product, engineering, and business leadership.
